Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 09:44PM Alyjens wrote: Binney, I just logged on after not checking the boards for quite awhile, and what a great surprise to discover that you have been recognised for all your contributions to our "swell" community.  I know that for me personally, when I was first diagnosed with LE a year ago, you were a calming, supportive and informative voice.  I tell my local LE support group that you are like the "mother" to us Swell Sisters.  Congratulations for you're well deserved award and a big "thank you" from me for all you do.
Posts.Title: CONGRATS TO OUR DR. BINNEY! OneBadBoob gracejon

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2008 02:09AM Alyjens wrote: Sharon, are the fingers of these gloves much longer than your fingers?  The reason I ask is that I've gotten several types of gloves and the fingers are all too long for me.  I've tried different sizes of surgical gloves, but the sz that fits over my compression glove has long fingers.  It's ok for cleaning, but I am really in need of something I can use for cooking-like chopping up ingredients. The floppy ends and knives don't really mix.   Floppy finger ends also get in the way with kneading and forming dough.  I used to be able to whip up a batch of scones in no time.  Now it seems to take me forever. Fran, you are a role model for making the best of a lousy situation!  I'm going to keep you in mind when I have one of my "woe is me" days.    I'm so sorry that the stupid Disability regulations required you to do that surgery which left you with an even bigger problem!  It sounds so Big Brothery.  Glad to hear you have such a supportive husband.  My husband has been great helping me, too. I don't know what I'd do without him.  Stay well! {{{Hugs}}} Alyjens
Posts.Title: SO, HOW DO YOU COPE???!!! Binney4 sisterinspirit

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 12:54AM Alyjens wrote: Hi Debbie, Isn't it amazing how much this LE can cost?!  I have a $40 copay for each MLD session and insurance only covers 1/2 of medical supplies. You should definately call them.  Your garment should be covered if ordered when insurance was effective.  I was concerned with my out of pocket costs and the American Cancer Society sent me a letter of organizations that help with LE supplies and copays.  I don't know how much they would help but it's worth a try.  Maybe the ACS could give you some assistence with the insurance issue, too?  If you send me a private message, I'll email the list to you.  Also, most people don't know that if they receive services at a non-profit hospital, they may qualify for reduced out of pocket expense.  My hospital in PA, has a sliding scale depending on income and I was surprised how high the threshold was to qualify for the first discount level. I only found out about it a couple months ago and I used to work there until the bc!   It's worth looking into.  It really helped me handle the therapy costs. Good luck to you Thurs and prayers that you get your garments soon. Alyjens
Posts.Title: Key links to Lymphedema pages on bc.o site Melissa kira

Posts.Content: Alyjens wrote: Hi all!  I'm in a Cancer Fit exercise program and today one of the women there talked about how sitting on one of those huge exercise balls and gently bouncing stimulates the lymphatic system as well as the adrenals.  Has anyone here ever heard of this.  I know I've heard that a rebounder is good for LE, but I have bad knees and can't do that.  This was fun and didn't hurt my knees at all. Alyjens Dx 12/14/2007, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 1/25 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: exercise ball Alyjens Binney4

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2008 01:30PM Alyjens wrote: Binney, this is the context of the letter I received from the American Cancer Society in PA:       .....included is a list of possible resoures for assistance with lymphedema suppies and copays.  Please contact each and explain your situation.  There may be eligibility criteria, but they will be able to clarify their services when you call. Patient Advocate Foundation (PAF)    866-512-3861 Living Beyond Breast Cancer             610-645-4567   (local PA number, but worth a try) Linda Creed Breast Cancer Foundation  877-992-7333 American Breast Cancer Foundation (ABCF)  877-539-2543 Patient Access Network Foundation (PANF)   866-316-7263 HealthWell Foundation        800-675-8416 CancerCare              800-813-4673 I don't know if these are local to me in the Phila, PA area or not.  So far, between the help the hospital is giving me and my insurance, I haven't felt the need to call.  Though with my upcoming rads, if I can't work for a while, I'll need to.  It can't hurt to call them and see if they are a national organization or not.  Or I would suggest calling your local ACS and seeing if they have their own list of resources for your area. Hope this helps some of you! Alyjens
Posts.Title: Key links to Lymphedema pages on bc.o site Melissa kira

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2008 12:01PM Alyjens wrote: Doreen, thank you so much for these links!  The recipe looks really easy.  The only thing that worries me is when you stir in the flour.  Is it heavy and hard to stir in?  My arm doesn't have much strength these days.    And I injured my left arm trying to lift too much with it. Thanks! Alyjens
Posts.Title: How does lymphedema affect your life? jinky Binney4

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 03:27AM Alyjens wrote: Great list, Doe and eveyone!  I agree with all the above and want to add that I used to enjoy cooking, now it's a chore trying to figure out how to not get my sleeve/glove dirty and it's hard to chop ingredients with a plastic glove on to protect it.  Used to make bread and scones, now can't knead the dough very well.  I am so sick of depending on my husband for lifting things, opening jars, doing a lot of the housework. (bless him-he never complains. He really empathizes with what I've lost to limitations) I miss my crafts:  knitting, crocheting, beading.  I have LE in my dominant arm along with some mild neuropathy in my thumb and first 2 fingers.  Even reading is hard since holding a book for a length of time gets my arm aching along with the fingers.  And forget about a heavy hardback book!  Velcro has become my enemy.  It's everywhere and wrecks my expensive compression garments! I can't work full time anymore since I can't tolerate hours of the writing and computer keying my job requires, as well as filing and pulling heavy charts. (medical office).  I used to also have a part time job, too.  So the 45-50 hrs a week have shrunk to 20 along with my paycheck.  The out of pocket expenses for PT and garments compounds this. Jinky, driving bothers me, too, and I find that my ability to steer is "weaker". Jane,  I want to go to bed without being all wrapped up, too.  I've given up feeling "sexy" going to bed and my solution is to just stay up half the night. Kira, I totally agree with this being an "orphan disease" and the medical professionals don't have a good understanding of it and minimize it's effects on us.  I also agree that the LE doesn't let you put the bc behind you.  I could deal pretty well with the bc, treat it and get on with life.  The LE not so much.  You summed it up so well with your statement that "My body swelled and my life shrunk".  I am in mourning for my life before LE. Hugs to all of you! Alyjens
Posts.Title: How does lymphedema affect your life? jinky Binney4
